conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas during the transition from state C to state D, we need to analyze the process depicted on the given P-V diagram.
The transition from state C to state D occurs at a constant pressure (isobaric process).
The pressure remains constant at \( p = 0.75 \times 10^5 \) Pa throughout this process.
At state C, the volume is \( V_C = 4 \) L.
At state D, the volume is \( V_D = 3 \) L.

premise: At state C, the volume is \( V_C = 4 \) L. At state D, the volume is \( V_D = 3 \) L.
conclusion: The change in volume (\( \Delta V \)) is \( \Delta V = V_D - V_C = 3 \text{ L} - 4 \text{ L} = -1 \text{ L} \).
For an isobaric process, the work done by the gas is given by the formula \( W = p \cdot \Delta V \).

premise: The pressure remains constant at \( p = 0.75 \times 10^5 \) Pa. The change in volume is \( \Delta V = -1 \text{ L} \).
conclusion: Substituting the values: \( W = 0.75 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \times (-1 \text{ L}) \).

premise: Convert the volume from liters to cubic meters (\(1 \text{ L} = 1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3\)).
conclusion: The work done is \( W = 0.75 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \times (-1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3) \).

premise: The work done is \( W = 0.75 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \times (-1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3) \).

conclusion: The work done is \( W = -75 \text{ J} \).
